subject: Re: [junit] textui.TestRunner exit codes

messageBody:
On Thu, 28 Mar 2002, kentlbeck wrote:
> There is a proposal afoot to change the exit codes for the
> textui.TestRunner from -1 and -2 to indicate the presence of errors
> and failures, respectively, to 1 and 2. Some shells don't handle
> negative return codes correctly, turning them into 0 (meaning normal
> termination, which seems like the wrong way to truncate, but what do
> I know). Would anyone object to this change? Who out there uses the
> exit codes?

We use the exit code in our project during an automated daily
build/verification process. We assume 0 means success, non-0 otherwise.
Personally I wish the errors and failures were rolled into just
1 category (a bug is a bug).

If you are curious, the log gets emailed out to the team with a subject
that mentions (sucess) or (errors) depending on if everything was ok.
Basically ksh/cron type stuff, which uses the exit codes to detect
errors. Since it gets emailed out every night, it detects lapses in
judgement at most 24 hours after they happen and alerts everybody.
Mostly the integration type tests fail though (which are not implemented
with junit) because of database issues, or the build fails because
permissions in CVS are wrong... stuff like that. So then you can look
at the attachements (log files, junit textui output) to figure out what
went wrong when the subject says "... (errors) ...".

We use ksh, perl, tcsh and bash across several unix flavors (sgi and
solaris, mainly) and cygwin under windows.

I hope that helps you. Let me know if you require further details.
